indicators.justification:
Sierra Leone does not actively collect and publish data on emissions. The Meteorological Agency, the body responsible for weather and climate issues supports the publication of Sierra Leone's National communications (TNC) to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). However, the last submission which was done in 2017 is not relevant for this assessment. Furthermore, detailed emission data is not available online.

Sources:


### References
Gabriel Kpaka, Deputy Director-General, Sierra Leone Metrological Office

indicators.justification:
The Conservation Society Sierra Leone, a local non-profit affiliated to Bird Life International keeps an offline list of all endangered species in Sierra Leone. It is possible to visit and physically inspect these data at their Freetown office. This information is not available online(1). However, a website known as Earth's Endangered Creatures, http://earthsendangered.com, maintains a list of endangerd species globally. The data can be filtered by country and type of species. However, this data is not open since there are a number of restrictions on re-use. In particular users are required to take permission before using text and images (2).
Another organization, Mongabay, a nonprofit environmental media organization, keeps similar data but the last update was made in September 2019(3).

Sources:
(1) Conservation Society Sierra Leone, https://www.birdlife.org/africa/partners/sierra-leone-conservation-society-sierra-leone-cssl

(2) Earth Endangered Creatures, http://www.earthsendangered.com/reference.asp

(3) Mongobay, https://rainforests.mongabay.com/biodiversity/en/sierra_leone/CR.html

###Reference
(1) Hassan Bangura, activist and former Communications Officer, Conservation Society Sierra Leone.

indicators.justification:
About 50% of all court cases in Sierra Leone are said to be land-related. Land data is not currently open. Persons who need to obtain land data would need to use the Right to Access Information Act, 2013 (1), or depend on an insider for help (3). Online searches including on the government's open data portal revealed the absence of land tenure data online. Lack of data and transparency within the sector allows the fraudulent transaction of land to multiple sources.

indicators.justification:
In June 2021, Sierra Leone passed the cybersecurity bill to address some of the regulatory gaps in the country's digital space. Notwithstanding this progressive move, the said bill does not adequately address issues of 'choice and consent', duties of data holders, and redress mechanisms for data breaches. Other existing laws including Section 22 of the country's Constitution also only partially address data privacy or protection needs (1). While many institutions and businesses develop internal policies to enhance data protection and privacy, these policies cannot be said to have the full force of the law.

indicators.justification:
Section 20, subsection 2c of The Public Financial Management Act 2016 only generally requires public institutions to furnish the public with information on fiscal objectives, policies, data, and risks(1). It states:  Notwithstanding the generality of subsection 1, any
person, institution, or agency referred to under subsection 1, shall be guided by the following principles of responsible financial management–
provide timely, reliable, and adequate information to the public on fiscal objectives, policies, data, and risks to ensure transparency in the budgetary and financial management of the general government and public enterprises;
Section 33, subsection 3 further stipulates that the national budget be gazetted and then published on the website of the Ministry of Finance(2).
However, these provisions do not specifically require that the data be structured nor do they provide guidelines on the type and quality of data to publish. In the same vein, the Right to Access Information Act is also limited.

Sources:

indicators.justification:
Sierra Leone's Anti-Corruption laws provide for the collection of data on the income, assets, and liabilities of public officers and their spouses and children(1). However, the same laws treat with secrecy such declared assets and income. Furthermore, asset declaration is still paper-based. An EU-sponsored initiative to allow web-based declaration is not currently functional.
It is therefore highly unlikely that the Anti-Corruption Commission currently keeps a structured aggregated database of the declarations made.
